p: As a simple low‐cost process, germination is an effective technology for improving the nutritional and functional qualities of soybean: (a) the degradation of the antinutritional factors and trypsin inhibitor (Bau, Villaume, Nicolas, & Méjean, 2015; Harini, Basetty, Jasti, Lavanya, & Fadnavis, 2017); (b) the accumulation of bioactive phytochemicals, including vitamins, phytosterols, and tocopherols (Kaushik, Satya, & Naik, 2010); (c) the enhancement of isoflavone content (Chen & Chang, 2015); and (d) oligosaccharides hydrolysis (raffinose and stachyose; Félix et al., 2013). Moreover, the content and digestibility of soluble proteins are also improved during germination process (Bau et al., 2015). However, only a few studies have been devoted to assess the effect of germination on the physicochemical property, antioxidant, and cytoprotective effect of soy proteins.
